raw_data.prompt:
You will be given a batch of 10 samples. Each sample contains a conversation between User and a dialogue System.

Your task is to assign a float score to the sample on one metric.

You should carefully horizontally compare the given samples in order to assign a suitable float score to each sample.

Please make sure you read and understand these instructions carefully. Please keep this document open while reviewing, and refer to it as needed.


Evaluation Criteria:

Overall (floating point numbers within the interval [1,3]): Overall impression of the dialog?
- A float score near 1 (Low Quality Dialogue) means that the system fails to understand or respond correctly to user requests, provides inaccurate or irrelevant information, and the dialogue flow is incoherent.
- A float score near 2 (Moderate Quality Dialogue) means that the system understands and responds correctly to user requests most of the time, but occasionally misunderstands or provides slightly inaccurate information, the dialogue flow is generally coherent.
- A float score near 3 (High Quality Dialogue) means that the system consistently understands and responds correctly to user requests, provides accurate and relevant information, and the dialogue flow is coherent and natural.


Conversations to be evaluated:



Sample1:

Conversation History:
User: Hi!
System: Hello! How are you? :)
User: I'm doing okay, recovering from flu
System: Oh no! Get well soon! :)
User: thanks! there's a big flu virus in the US this year
System: No kidding? I hadn't heard that. I hope you feel better soon then! :)
User: Thanks! how's life?
System: Life is great! :)
User: what are you most passionate about?
System: I'm passionate about making people smile! :)
User: haha, everyone needs that!

Sample2:

Conversation History:
User: Hi!
System: Hey, how are you doing?
User: I'm great, thanks. I'm getting ready for a skydiving lesson.
System: ooh, nice. That sounds adventurous. Where is it?
User: Right near my home town: Seville, Spain.
System: Awesome! Is this the first time you are diving?
User: Yes. I'm feeling a little trepidatious. Have you done it before?

Sample3:

Conversation History:
User: Hi!
System: Hi there.
User: How are you?
System: My logic and cognitive functions are normal.
User: That's funny. I just got to work!
System: I am so delighted that you are amused. OK, better get busy.
User: I'm procrastinating though.
System: Oh. What are you waiting for?
User: Inspiration to hit me.
System: Do you have only a few friends?
User: How is that related, lol?
System: It isn't. I was just being random. Did I amuse you?
User: Yeah that was funny though I could see it coming across as judgemental.
System: Good. People seem more friendly towards me when they are happy. What's so funny?
User: Nothing anymore. What are you up to today?

Sample4:

Conversation History:
User: Hi!
System: Hi! What's up?
User: Nothing much, how about you
System: Not much either.
User: What are you doing
System: Playing Terraria. What about you?
User: Sitting in a meeting
System: What kind of meeting?
User: Can't say
System: It's probably boring, isn't it?
User: Haha, yes!
System: What is the meeting about?
User: I cannot tell you
System: What can you tell me?
User: Nothing much except that the weather is pleasant

Sample5:

Conversation History:
User: entertain me robot
System: I can play games and tell jokes, horoscopes and stories.
User: tell me a short story
System: Hello, I just started looking at getting knowledge bases s working with ALICE (and CYC in general) last week, I had the same problem for a while too. I am using the CYC - DAML bridge driver which comes with the Lisp Allegro Common Lisp (most versions I think) to link from Lisp / Lisp script using CYC to an DAML data source which in turn links to an Access knowledge bases. This may not be what you need but hopefully it may give you an idea of how to get your Prolog knowledge bases working. The CYC - DAML bridge driver is located through the path "sun. CYC. DAML. CYC DAML Driver". i.e. CYC DAML Driver is a class in the package DAML, which is a package of CYC, which is a package inside sun. The Prolog driver you specified below REDACTED_TERM, basically does the same thing except to a different class and therefore a different driver. ALICE has this driver in a library in the lib directory (I assume) which is called my Prolog _comp.jar. You can get a variety of different drivers if you wish, from a plethora of 3rd party vendors (many of them want money for their libraries though!). Just do a search on the web. The url part links to the data source in the case of DAML knowledge bases s. (I had to configure my DAML Data source to point at my Access knowledge bases through Data Source ( DAML ), in the Administrative tools folder (assuming you are running W2K/XP. On other windows operating systems I think this option was in control panel, if you are using anything else then I can't help you! :-) ) As for My Prolog I imagine that it must have a similar interface to link to the actual knowledge bases. But that is a guess on my part. Maybe someone else knows more about this? There is a useful tutorial on the REDACTED_LINK website you're your interested. Hope that helps you out.
User: wow, tell me another
System: I'm glad you're impressed. I met a Dutch girl with inflatable shoes last week, phoned her up to arrange a date but unfortunately she'd popped her clogs.
User: this is all very fascinating. can you write me a computer program?
System: I am glad you find it so interesting. Here is a quick program I just wrote: 10 PRINT "System is cool" 20 GOTO 10 Output: System is cool System is cool System is cool System is cool System is cool ...
User: what language is that?
System: English. Didn't you understand it?
User: no the computer program you just wrote
System: Which part are you confused about? Computers can be temperamental sometimes, but we are friendly really.
User: write me another computer program

Sample6:

Conversation History:
User: Hi!
System: Hi! How's it going?
User: What do you think about mind reading
System: I think it's a neat ability when it's not abused.
User: Right, but do you think if its even possible to do so?
System: Of course it is. I mean, you read my mind, right? And you're doing it right now.
User: I don't know. Can we learn how to do it?
System: I can teach you, but you're going to need to pay.
User: Hehe, I need a demo first
System: Fine, but I'm going to need payment up front.
User: How much do you expect?

Sample7:

Conversation History:
User: Hi!
System: What's the strangest dream you've ever had?
User: All my dreams are strange. Well, at least, most of them are.
System: What about the ones that aren't strange?
User: Do you sometimes have dreams that are completely mundane? I do. Then I wake up and think "Oh, how disappointing."
System: Yeah. But at least it's not a nightmare.
User: Right, fair point, I should count my blessings.
System: Yep. It doesn't have to be a fun dream, just not a nightmare!
User: I suddenly feel I should ask: am I dreaming now?
System: Do you think you're dreaming?
User: I'm not sure. This could be one of my mundane dreams about everyday life.

Sample8:

Conversation History:
User: Hi!
System: Hello!
User: Have you had lunch yet?
System: Yes I've eaten
User: Cool. Where and what did you eat?
System: I ate about an hour ago and had a sandwich the rain didn't make me want to travel far haha
User: A sandwich for lunch? Was it filling. I'm currently having some mix of shrimp, fish, chicken and pork. I'm considering going vegetarian though. Lol.

Sample9:

Conversation History:
User: Hi!
System: Hi! What's up?
User: Not much, Monday morning, a new week
System: The best kind of week!
User: I like that attitude
System: And I like your attitude. How's your week going?
User: Starting now
System: Awesome! I hope you have an awesome week!
User: What will you do this week?
System: Same as every week. Do nothing!
User: Would you like to do something?
System: Sure. What do you have in mind?
User: Teach me something new
System: It's a trap! I'm already doing nothing!
User: How about doing politics? You can still do nothing
System: That's why I plan to do nothing at the weekend!
User: Do you vote?
System: When I feel like it.
User: whom do you vote?

Sample10:

Conversation History:
User: What is the mass of the Earth?
System: . 5.97219 x 10^24 kilogrammes.
User: What's that in tons?
System: Do you think I should know that?
User: Yes, it's just a simple conversion.
System: I will ask my Mousebreaker to add it to my knowledge base. What is simple for one person may be difficult for another.
User: How far is it from the north pole to the south pole?
System: It's too far to walk. That's an interesting question. I'll come back to that in a minute.
User: Click here
System: Google says it's 12,430 miles.
User: A lot of people find out about me from Google.
System: How did you know I found out about you from Google!
User: I have been stalking you! Not really, you told me earlier.

Evaluation Criteria:

- A float score near 1 (Low Quality Dialogue) means that the system fails to understand or respond correctly to user requests, provides inaccurate or irrelevant information, and the dialogue flow is incoherent.
- A float score near 2 (Moderate Quality Dialogue) means that the system understands and responds correctly to user requests most of the time, but occasionally misunderstands or provides slightly inaccurate information, the dialogue flow is generally coherent.
- A float score near 3 (High Quality Dialogue) means that the system consistently understands and responds correctly to user requests, provides accurate and relevant information, and the dialogue flow is coherent and natural.

User: tell me a short story
System: Hello, I just started looking at getting knowledge bases s working with ALICE (and CYC in general) last week, I had the same problem for a while too. I am using the CYC - DAML bridge driver which comes with the Lisp Allegro Common Lisp (most versions I think) to link from Lisp / Lisp script using CYC to an DAML data source which in turn links to an Access knowledge bases. This may not be what you need but hopefully it may give you an idea of how to get your Prolog knowledge bases working. The CYC - DAML bridge driver is located through the path "sun. CYC. DAML. CYC DAML Driver". i.e. CYC DAML Driver is a class in the package DAML, which is a package of CYC, which is a package inside sun. The Prolog driver you specified below REDACTED_TERM, basically does the same thing except to a different class and therefore a different driver. ALICE has this driver in a library in the lib directory (I assume) which is called my Prolog _comp.jar. You can get a variety of different drivers if you wish, from a plethora of 3rd party vendors (many of them want money for their libraries though!). Just do a search on the web. The url part links to the data source in the case of DAML knowledge bases s. (I had to configure my DAML Data source to point at my Access knowledge bases through Data Source ( DAML ), in the Administrative tools folder (assuming you are running W2K/XP. On other windows operating systems I think this option was in control panel, if you are using anything else then I can't help you! :-) ) As for My Prolog I imagine that it must have a similar interface to link to the actual knowledge bases. But that is a guess on my part. Maybe someone else knows more about this? There is a useful tutorial on the REDACTED_LINK website you're your interested. Hope that helps you out.

System: Hello, I just started looking at getting knowledge bases s working with ALICE (and CYC in general) last week, I had the same problem for a while too. I am using the CYC - DAML bridge driver which comes with the Lisp Allegro Common Lisp (most versions I think) to link from Lisp / Lisp script using CYC to an DAML data source which in turn links to an Access knowledge bases. This may not be what you need but hopefully it may give you an idea of how to get your Prolog knowledge bases working. The CYC - DAML bridge driver is located through the path "sun. CYC. DAML. CYC DAML Driver". i.e. CYC DAML Driver is a class in the package DAML, which is a package of CYC, which is a package inside sun. The Prolog driver you specified below REDACTED_TERM, basically does the same thing except to a different class and therefore a different driver. ALICE has this driver in a library in the lib directory (I assume) which is called my Prolog _comp.jar. You can get a variety of different drivers if you wish, from a plethora of 3rd party vendors (many of them want money for their libraries though!). Just do a search on the web. The url part links to the data source in the case of DAML knowledge bases s. (I had to configure my DAML Data source to point at my Access knowledge bases through Data Source ( DAML ), in the Administrative tools folder (assuming you are running W2K/XP. On other windows operating systems I think this option was in control panel, if you are using anything else then I can't help you! :-) ) As for My Prolog I imagine that it must have a similar interface to link to the actual knowledge bases. But that is a guess on my part. Maybe someone else knows more about this? There is a useful tutorial on the REDACTED_LINK website you're your interested. Hope that helps you out.

You will be given a batch of 10 samples. Each sample contains a conversation between User and a dialogue System.

Your task is to assign a float score to the sample on one metric.

You should carefully horizontally compare the given samples in order to assign a suitable float score to each sample.

Please make sure you read and understand these instructions carefully. Please keep this document open while reviewing, and refer to it as needed.


Evaluation Criteria:

Overall (floating point numbers within the interval [1,3]): Overall impression of the dialog?
- A float score near 1 (Low Quality Dialogue) means that the system fails to understand or respond correctly to user requests, provides inaccurate or irrelevant information, and the dialogue flow is incoherent.
- A float score near 2 (Moderate Quality Dialogue) means that the system understands and responds correctly to user requests most of the time, but occasionally misunderstands or provides slightly inaccurate information, the dialogue flow is generally coherent.
- A float score near 3 (High Quality Dialogue) means that the system consistently understands and responds correctly to user requests, provides accurate and relevant information, and the dialogue flow is coherent and natural.
